original_content:
Over the couple of decades or so since it started to be available at an affordable level, 3D printing has revolutionized the process of making custom objects. But as anyone with a 3D printer will know, sometimes the materials dont quite live up to the application. There is a huge variety of available filaments to help make better prints, but which one really is the most hard-wearing? [My Tech Fun] set out to measure the resistance to wear of a variety of different 3D printed materials.
The test takes a standard print made across a variety of different materials, and several of each using different manufacturers offerings. These are then put on a test rig that moves backward and forward twice a second, with the test piece rubbing against a steel shaft under pressure from a 2.5 kg weight.
As might be expected, the common and cheap PLA performed the worst while PETG, PA, and TPU performed the best. But for us the interesting part comes in the variance between brands; the best PLA sample outperforms the worst ABS and nearly equals the worst of the PETG. Proof that maybe you do get what you pay for.
The whole test is well worth a watch, and if you 3D print anything that might be subjected to mechanical stress you should find it to be of interest. If comparing filaments is something youd like to see more of, weve featured some tests before.
title: 3Dプリント素材の耐摩耗性テスト結果
body: 3Dプリントで使う素材の耐久性をテストした結果、安価なPLAよりもPETG、PA、TPUの方が優れていた。ブランドによる差もあり、価格と品質は連動していることが示唆されていた。
titles: 3Dプリント素材の耐摩耗性テスト結果
異なる3Dプリント素材の耐久性を比較
3Dプリンター用フィラメントの性能比較
プリント時の耐久性が問題？異なる素材の比較検証
3Dプリント素材の耐久性に着目したテスト結果
